resource.chars:
It must not however be supposed that all the
great physical features of the Highlands are connected
with the foliation of the Gneiss & Schists: there have
been many disturbing forces at work at various later
periods which have broken up the surface into
hills & valleys with very different directions. The 
most important of these are connected with the
outbursts of Granite, Porphyry & similar rocks
far more numerous than are represented on any of our maps
which have broken through the Gneiss & Schists
& deranged the regularity of their foliation. <s>Often<\s> Many
districts also may have been disturbed by agents which
have not shown themselves on the surface; of
these, the neighbourhood of Loch Lomond is <s>the most<\s> a
remarkable instance. <s>I observed.<\s> But as <s>I regard<\s>
the Gneiss <s>as<\s> appears to be the most ancient of the formations
now visible in Scotland, so also <s>I consider<\s> the
physical features connected with the foliation
of the Gneiss <s>as<\s> must be regarded as the earliest of which we
can take cognizance, & we must refer to later periods
those which appear to be independent of that
phenomenon.
